_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Dry, Condensed, and Evaporated Dairy Product Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Foremost Farms USA Cooperative approaches chemical hazards seriously, devoting staff and management at the plant, as well as the corporate level.  Foremost Farms is committed to safety for employees, the public, and the environment and strives to meet all appropriate federal, state, and local environmental and safety regulations.    

Foremost Farm Richland Center facility is located at 684 South Church Street, Richland Center, Wisconsin.  The facility manufactures dairy products including mozzarella cheese and whey products.  Raw milk is trucked to the facility and stored in silos.  The milk and finished cheese products are refrigerated using an ammonia refrigeration system (ARS).  Anhydrous ammonia has been used as a refrigerant by the food industry for decades.  An ARS contains ammonia is various states including liquid, vapor, and gas in various vessels, compressors, condensers, pipes, and evaporators.  

On June 26, 1996, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) published Title 40, Part 68 of the Code of Federal Regulations (40 CFR 68).  The intent of the Rule is to prevent accidental releases of toxic substances and to identify potential impacts to public and environmental receptors.  This Rule requires that covered facilities develop and implement a Risk Management Program.  40 CFR 68 regulates anhydrous ammonia when used in a process at amounts greater than the threshold quantity (TQ) of 10,000 pounds.  The Foremost Farms Facility has undergone renovation in 2000-2001.  The previous ARS did not contain ammonia above the TQ and therefore was not subject to 40 CFR 68.  Upon plant expansion the old ARS was decommissioned and a new ARS was installed.  The new ARS at Foremost Farms in Richland Center has a capacity of anhydrous ammonia over the TQ and the refrigeration process will be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR 68, therefore this RMP is being submitted for the newly covered process.    

The Risk Management Program

rule requires that a covered facility evaluate two ammonia release scenarios, the "worst-case" release and an "alternative" release.  The worst-case release for the Richland Center Foremost Farms plant is the loss of the ammonia in the high pressure receiver vessel at maximum capacity.  The alternative release scenario is a cracked coil.  Given the safety precautions at the plant and state of the art ARS equipment, both releases are unlikely.  If a release occurred , however, the alternative scenario would be more likely.  Both ammonia releases were modeled with EPAs RMP Comp software(version 1.06) and Ammonia Guidances.  Both the worst case and alternative releases result in off-site impacts.  

As mentioned above, releases from the ARS are unlikely.    Foremost Farms Richland Center complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (the PSM Standard) to reduce the possibility of accidental release of highly hazardous chemicals. The PSM standard  (29 CFR 1910.119) is designed to protect employees by preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases of toxic, reactive, flammable or explosive chemicals.  Facilities using a regulated substance (i.e. ammonia) in excess of a regulated (TQ) are required to develop and implement a PSM program. The OSHA PSM standard can be used to satisfy the prevention program element of EPA's Risk Management Program.  The PSM standard addresses the following 12 areas of the prevention program: 
  
? Employee Participation
? Process Safety Information
? Process Hazard Analysis
? Operating Procedures
? Training
? Mechanical Integrity 
? Management of Change
? Pre-Start up Safety Review
? Compliance Audits
? Incident Investigation
? Employee Participation
? Hot Work Permits
? Contractor Safety

There are several aspects of the prevention program at Richland Center Foremost Farms that are key:

1. Foremost Farms ensures it's employees are aware of

the ARS system, it's risks, and the prevention program elements in place.

2. Design included safety considerations.  For example, major pieces of refrigeration equipment have automatic detection, alarm, and shutdown controls and most ammonia piping is located along ceilings away from people and moving equipment, therefore ammonia releases from accidents are unlikely. 

3. The plant maintains training programs for it's employees involved with the ARS.

4. Operating procedures are followed and updated as needed.

5. Mechanical integrity and management of change programs are maintained and used.

6. Process hazards are re-evaluated periodically.

7. The PSM program goes through a scheduled compliance audit process to verify elements are being implemented. 

The Foremost Farms Richland Center facility has an emergency response program implemented.  The emergency response program includes detailed emergency communication procedures, emergency evacuation procedures, and an off-site plan.  Key elements of the emergency response plan include:

1. Foremost personnel are trained in emergency response and use of self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA) equipment for responses to ammonia leaks.

2. Non-essential personnel are evacuated from the area affected by the release.

3. If an off-site release occurs, Foremost will contact local officials to notify neighbors.
